events.title: Birth
events.summary: Domenico Scarlatti was born in Naples, in a family of ten children. His father, Alessandro Scarlatti, was a composer and teacher, which likely influenced his early musical education.
events.fun_version: Domenico Scarlatti, born in Naples as one of ten children, must have experienced musical chaos during family gatherings. With his father, Alessandro Scarlatti—a composer and teacher—guiding him, it’s no surprise he learned music early; you can’t let that many siblings run around without something to distract them!

events.title: Appointment as Composer and Organist
events.summary: Scarlatti was appointed as a composer and organist at the Chapel Royal of Naples. He also briefly worked under his father who was then the chapel's maestro di cappella.
events.fun_version: Scarlatti was appointed as a composer and organist at the Chapel Royal of Naples. He briefly worked under his father, who was the chapel's maestro di cappella — talk about mixing family with authority!

events.title: Service to Queen Marie Casimire
events.summary: In 1709, Scarlatti entered the service of the exiled Polish queen Marie Casimire in Rome, where he composed several operas for her private theatre.
events.fun_version: In 1709, Scarlatti entered the service of the exiled Polish queen Marie Casimire in Rome, where he composed several operas for her private theatre. It sounds like a lavish setup, but I can only imagine her cat and a few very bored courtiers were his biggest fans!

events.title: Maestro di Cappella at St. Peter's
events.summary: Scarlatti served as Maestro di Cappella at St. Peter's from 1715 to 1719, contributing significantly to the musical life of the church.
events.fun_version: Scarlatti served as Maestro di Cappella at St. Peter's from 1715 to 1719, where he was the original playlist curator of church music, ensuring hymns didn’t sound like your grandma’s old mixtape!

events.title: Arrival in Lisbon
events.summary: Scarlatti arrived in Lisbon on 29 November 1719, where he taught music to the Portuguese princess Maria Magdalena Barbara.
events.fun_version: Scarlatti arrived in Lisbon on 29 November 1719. While there, he took on the monumental task of teaching music to the Portuguese princess Maria Magdalena Barbara, who was probably just trying to learn how to play 'Twinkle, Twinkle, Little Star.'

events.title: Travel to London
events.summary: In 1719, Scarlatti travelled to London to direct his opera Narciso at the King's Theatre, showcasing his works internationally.
events.fun_version: In 1719, Scarlatti decided to hop on a carriage and brave the streets of London to direct his opera Narciso at the King's Theatre, showcasing his works internationally. I mean, someone had to teach the Brits that the real reason for travel was to showcase opera and not just to complain about the weather!

events.title: Marriage
events.summary: Scarlatti married Maria Caterina Gentili in Rome on 6 May 1728, marking a significant personal event in his life.
events.fun_version: Scarlatti married Maria Caterina Gentili in Rome on 6 May 1728, marking a significant personal event in his life. Who knew that marrying in Rome was a way to ensure every fight ended with pizza and pasta? Talk about a romantic dinner date gone historical!

events.title: Move to Seville
events.summary: In 1729, Scarlatti moved to Seville, where he spent four years creating music for various patrons.
events.fun_version: In 1729, Scarlatti decided that moving to Seville was a great way to ignite his creativity. After all, nothing screams ‘musical genius’ like four years of serenading the patrons while trying not to get distracted by all the tapas!

events.title: Move to Madrid
events.summary: In 1733, Scarlatti moved to Madrid as a music master to Princess Maria Barbara, beginning a long stay in Spain that lasted for 25 years.
events.fun_version: In 1733, Scarlatti cha-cha-chased his way to Madrid as a music master to Princess Maria Barbara—because who wouldn't want to spend 25 years in Spain teaching a royal how to tickle the ivories? Rumor has it, the princess never got tired of his piano performances!

events.title: Marrying Again
events.summary: After the death of his first wife in 1739, Scarlatti married Anastasia Maxarti Ximenes, illustrating the personal trials he faced.
events.fun_version: In 1739, after his first wife decided to take a permanent vacation, Scarlatti thought it was time for another wife. He tied the knot with Anastasia Maxarti Ximenes, illustrating the personal trials he faced, showing how personal trials can be plot twists in anyone's life!

events.title: Death
events.summary: Scarlatti died in Madrid at the age of 71, leaving behind a rich legacy in classical music. His residence is marked with a historical plaque today.
events.fun_version: Scarlatti passed away in Madrid at the age of 71, leaving behind a rich legacy in classical music. His residence is today marked with a historical plaque.
